node.title: configure error for submodule libmesh with external petsc on cluster
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am trying to configure the submodule libmesh inside moose with an external PETSc on cluster. The external PETSc was successfully installed and passed all test provided by PETSc. I have specified the correct PETSC_DIR when running ./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh in moose/scripts and PETSc was shown found. However, this is the error I got:
<<< Found PETSc 3.17.2 installation in /hpc/group/dolbowlab/bz75/petsc ... >>>
checking whether we can compile a trivial PETSc program... no
checking for TAO support via PETSc... no
configure: error: *** PETSc was not found, but --enable-petsc-required was specified.

The details related to PETSc not found in moose/libmesh/build/config.log are pasted below. I do have the missing files in my $PETSC_DIR/include.
(There are other error in the log file but I am not sure if they are the reason the configure was aborted. I can provide them if needed.)
configure:49429: result: <<< Found PETSc 3.17.2 installation in /hpc/group/dolbowlab/bz75/petsc ... >>>
configure:49439: checking whether we can compile a trivial PETSc program
configure:49470: mpicxx -std=gnu++17 -c     conftest.cpp >&5
conftest.cpp:155:20: fatal error: petsc.h: No such file or directory
  155 |           #include <petsc.h>
      |                    ^~~~~~~~~
compilation terminated.

Can you attach the libmesh_diagnostic.log which should reside in moose/scripts? It contains additional information that might help shed some light on the issue. If that file does not exist, please re-run moose/scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh using the same environment you plan on having it succeed in.
Also, can you provide the results of an ldd on a PETSc library you are using (this will help us understand what compiler was being used to build):
ldd $PETSC_DIR/lib/libpetsc.so

libmesh_diagnostic.log is here.
libmesh_diagnostic.log
The ldd on PETSc library I think do shown there is a problem with my installation. Here is what I got:
bz75@dcc-login-03  /hpc/group/dolbowlab/bz75/petsc $ ldd $PETSC_DIR/lib/libpetsc.so
ldd: /hpc/group/dolbowlab/bz75/petsc/lib/libpetsc.so: No such file or directory

Oh right, PETSC_ARCH (good observation!). I think your installation of PETSc is fine. The diagnostics indicate perhaps CC, CXX, etc need to be set. Can you try this, and report back (attaching those same logs):
export CC=mpicc CXX=mpicxx FC=mpif90 F90=mpif90 F77=mpif77
scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh
I do see that XDR has not been found. I am not sure if this will hinder you later down the road, but we might need your system administrator to install an additional library. We will deal with that when we run into it...

why are all warnings treated as errors? What are the compile flags?
3.17.2 is not officially supported yet.

The compile flags did treat all warning as error.
The warnings are gone after I switched to PETSc-3.16.5.

MOOSE will use what-ever-petsc libMesh was built against. And libMesh will either use what-ever PETSC_DIR is set to, or submodule petsc... But it would appear you have things running. So, your call on where we head next :)
While latest PETSc isn't supported, we applaud attempts and reporting back any fixes you may find/solve along the way!

I think this issue is solved.
However, I compiled this stand alone PETSc in hope to fix another issue, which remains an issue now. I am following the debug guide to produce backtrace. I will open a new discussion soon.
Thank you!

node.title: Plugin flags at app level
node.bodyText:
Is there anything that can be done at the app-level to change compile and/or include flags for plugins? I have an app with some UMAT  f90 files in a "plugins" directory on the app's root. I'm trying to add extra include dirs and compile flags to the Makefile but haven't managed to affect the way the plugins are being compiled.
@dschwen
@dschwen

LOL, noted. I think I figured it out though: set the PLUGIN_FLAGS variable in the app's Makefile. For example:
PLUGIN_FLAGS += -ffree-line-length-none -I$(CURDIR)/include

node.title: Compliance tensor is equal to nan
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I have following problem. I would like to calculate the phase-field stress distribution using Reuss-Sachs approximation, i.e.
$\mathbf{C} = \left( \sum h_{\alpha} \mathbf{S}_{\alpha} \right)^{-1}$
where $ h_{\alpha} $ is weighting function of the each particular phase and $\mathbf{S}_{\alpha}$ is compliance tensor of each phase.
My idea was to calculate the compliance tensor of each phase hard-coded inside of the stress calculation subroutine, i.e.
RankFourTensor compliance_alpha = _elasticity_tensor_alpha[_qp].inverse();
The elasticity tensor is constructed with ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor material, i.e.
[./elasticity_tensor_alpha]
type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
youngs_modulus = 1
poissons_ratio = 0.3
base_name = alpha_phase
[../]
The output inverse is estimated to be nan. If someone has idea, why the inversion operation results in nan values, I would like to discuss them!
Best regards,
Rostyslav Nizinkovskyi.
It shouldn't be nan given this pair of lame parameters. Where and how are you calculating the _elasticity_tensor_alpha?
For example, if you calculate the inverse before elasticity tensor is computed, you'll for sure get nan. You could try printing out the elasticity tensor right before the inversion.

Hi,
thank you for the reply and suggestions. _elasticity_tensor_alpha is consumed into material subroutine via
params.addRequiredParam<std::string>("base_name_alpha","Elasticity tensor of alpha phase eta = 1");
and
_base_name_alpha(getParam<std::string>("base_name_alpha") + "_"), _elasticity_tensor_alpha(getMaterialPropertyByName<RankFourTensor>(_base_name_alpha+"elasticity_tensor")),.
I had also tried to get output for the all values, which should be non-zero

As you can see, the values are non-zero and have a correspondent values. But the inversion is nevertheless nan (except for one value).
If you have further suggestions, I would like to consider them as well!
Hi! The invSymm method seems to work just correct! Thank you very much for the answer.

Dear @RossMech
You can see an example of inversion of RankFourTensor here:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/tensor_mechanics/unit/src/RankFourTensorTest.C
You need to specify where are you carrying out the inversion.
Is that inside a material object?
In that case, it is better to avoid doing the inversion inside the initQpStatefulProperties() function
because at that stage the elasticity tensor may not be yet calculated.
Best Regards,
Nicolò
Thank you for the answer! I use a ComputeStressBase as a starting point for my material development. The inversion is calculated inside of ComputeQpStress() function.
Also a little bit of additional information. In answer to @hugary1995 I had added an image, containing output of non-zero values of the stiffness and compliance tensors.

@RossMech  difficult to say, either the elasticity is not invertible for some reason, like components don't get filled completely. Or the class you use cannot be inverted. I suggest the following attempts to clarify:

Use without base name
Try printing _elasticity_tensor_alpha after the inversion operation, maybe inverse() is not meant to give an output and just invert the tensor
Try using another class instead of ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor, like ComputeElasticityTensorConstantRotationCP, like here:
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/crystal_plasticity/stress_update_material_based/linesearch.i
and try inverting _Cijkl instead.
If you can share the entire material class, it is easier to help.
Nicolò

1 & 3 aren't related to this issue as I see it.
2. inverse() isn't an in-place operation.
@ngrilli I am discussing this in #21211, feel free to take a look if you are interested.

node.title: INSAD failing to converge
node.bodyText:
Hi
I am trying to model fluid flow through a straight pipe as a simple benchmark. I have had good success using INSFV but I am now trying to use INSAD and struggling to get the solve to converge. Have tried making the mesh finer and messing around with various options to no avail.
Any suggestions welcome.
Jake

Input File

# 2d siumulation of a water through a pipe.

mu=1e-3 # Nsm^-2
rho=997.0 # kgm^-3
Re=1000.0
pipe_length=1 # m
pipe_radius=0.1 # m
u_inlet=${fparse (mu * Re)/(2 * pipe_radius * rho)} # ms^-1

[GlobalParams]
  integrate_p_by_parts = true
[]

[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    xmin = 0
    xmax = ${pipe_length}
    ymin = 0
    ymax = ${pipe_radius}
    nx = 1000
    ny = 100
  []
[]

[Problem]
  coord_type = 'RZ'
  rz_coord_axis = x
[]

[Variables]
  [./velocity]
    family = LAGRANGE_VEC
  [../]
  [./p]
  [../]
[]

[ICs]
  [velocity]
    type = VectorConstantIC
    x_value = 1e-15
    y_value = 1e-15
    variable = velocity
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [./mass]
    type = INSADMass
    variable = p
  [../]
  [./momentum_convection]
    type = INSADMomentumAdvection
    variable = velocity
  [../]

  [./momentum_viscous]
    type = INSADMomentumViscous
    variable = velocity
  [../]

  [./momentum_pressure]
    type = INSADMomentumPressure
    variable = velocity
    pressure = p
  [../]
[]

[BCs]
  [inlet]
    type = VectorFunctionDirichletBC
    variable = velocity
    boundary = 'left'
    function_x = ${u_inlet}
    function_y = 0
  [../]
  [wall]
    type = VectorFunctionDirichletBC
    variable = velocity
    boundary = 'top'
    function_x = 0
    function_y = 0
  []
  [axis]
    type = ADVectorFunctionDirichletBC
    variable = velocity
    boundary = 'bottom'
    set_x_comp = false
    function_y = 0
  []
  [outlet]
    type = INSADMomentumNoBCBC
    variable = velocity
    pressure = p
    boundary = 'right'
  []
  # When the NoBCBC is applied on the outlet boundary then there is nothing
  # constraining the pressure. Thus we must pin the pressure somewhere to ensure
  # that the problem is not singular. If the below BC is not applied then
  # -pc_type svd -pc_svd_monitor reveals a singular value
  [p_corner]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = 'right'
    value = 0
    variable = p
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [./const]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'rho mu'
    prop_values = '${rho} ${mu}'
  [../]
  [ins_mat]
    type = INSADMaterial
    velocity = velocity
    pressure = p
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
    solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady

  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -sub_pc_factor_levels -ksp_gmres_restart'
  petsc_options_value = 'asm      6                     200'
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-12
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-12
  l_max_its = 200
  line_search = 'none'
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

Hello
What is your Reynolds number? Do you expect the flow to be turbulent?
INSAD, which is based on finite element, requires numerical stabilization techniques such as PSPG or SUPG.
Guillaume

Hi
The Reynolds number is 1000 so the flow should be laminar.
Thanks again
Jake
I think you ll want to have stabilization as soon as Re>1

You could try raising the viscosity and decreasing the inlet velocity to see how far you get without stabilization but at 1000 I expect you ll need it
another thing that helps is to do a relaxation to steady state transient rather than solve with a steady executioner
Ok thanks, I am going to try adding stabilization first

So I have added stabilization and the solution now converges however the results are incorrect.

node.title: Huge element deformation for phase field fracture
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE Experts
I am trying to solve phase field fracture equation in chemo-mechanical environment.
Mesh which I am using is structured one.
As soon as the fracture evolves, the local elements deforms enormously (Figure attached).
I am using following solvers
solve_type = 'PJFNK'
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type -ksp_gmres_restart -snes_type'
petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg 300 vinewtonrsls'
automatic_scaling = true

Mesh size is resolved as per the length scale of phase field fracture.

Any thoughts or suggestions?
This could happen if the residual stiffness of the element is too small. Could you show us the definition of your degradation function?

The crack band is also much wider than I would expect, which also indicates that there may be some issues in the degradation function, e.g. the derivative of the degradation function w.r.t. damage isn't zero when the material is fully damaged.

Hello @hugary1995
Thanks. Sure, following is the definition of degradation function:

[./define_kappa]
type = ParsedMaterial
material_property_names = 'gc_prop l'
f_name = kappa_op
function = 'gc_prop * l'
[../]

[./damage_stress]
type = ComputeLinearElasticPFFractureStress
c = damage
E_name = 'elastic_energy'
D_name = 'degradation'
F_name = 'local_fracture_energy'
decomposition_type = stress_spectral
use_snes_vi_solver = true
[../]

[./degradation]
type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
f_name = degradation
args = 'damage'
function = '(1.0-damage)^2*(1.0 - eta) + eta'
constant_names       = 'eta'
constant_expressions = '1.0e-5'
derivative_order = 2
[../]

[./pfbulkmat]
type = GenericConstantMaterial
prop_names = 'R T cmax ki'
prop_values ='8.314             300           48976               1'
[../]

[./chemical_energy]
type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
f_name = chemical_energy
args = 'diffused'
material_property_names = 'R T cmax ki'
function = 'R*T*cmax*((diffused/cmax)*log(1-diffused/cmax) + (1-diffused/cmax)*log(1-diffused/cmax) + ki*(diffused/cmax)*(1.0-diffused/cmax))'
derivative_order = 2
[../]

[./local_fracture_energy]
type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
f_name = local_fracture_energy
args = 'damage'
material_property_names = 'gc_prop l'
function = 'damage^2 * gc_prop / 2 / l'
derivative_order = 2
[../]

[./fracture_driving_energy]
type = DerivativeSumMaterial
args = 'damage diffused'
sum_materials = 'elastic_energy local_fracture_energy chemical_energy'
derivative_order = 2
f_name = F
[../]

Best
Avtar

I am also including chemical energy as the driving force of fracture. Do you think it may be the culprit?
Also, My elastic modulus is the function of concentration.

Okay, thanks. eta is the residual stiffness I was referring to. But usually eta = 1e-5 is large enough to prevent issues like what you see. It seems that the chemical potential and the fracture potential are decoupled, so I don't see how the formulation could cause such huge deformation. The only other thing I can think of is maybe the solution hasn't really converged? What tolerances are you using?

I am also including chemical energy as the driving force of fracture. Do you think it may be the culprit? Also, My elastic modulus is the function of concentration.

But it seems to me your chemical energy is not a function of damage, so I don't think it is actually "driving" fracture. Did I miss something?

Yes, chemical energy is not a function of damage. but the diffusivity is the function of damage. And as soon as fracture occurs, the concentration is trapped within the damage zone (Figure attached). As elastic modulus is concentration dependent, I think it may cause the issue.
.
Following is the tolerances which I am using
l_max_its = 100
nl_max_its = 30
nl_abs_tol = 5e-3
l_tol = 1e-04
num_steps = 1500

Yeah, just make sure the elastic modulus doesn't drop all the way to zero as concentration increases. The nl_abs_tol is a little bit too high. I usually set nl_abs_tol = 1e-6 at most, assuming variables are unity scaled.

Hello @hugary1995
I put nl_abs_tol = 1e-6 for my simulation.
You are right. Its a convergence issue. It's not converging now.
Time Step 251, time = 502, dt = 2
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 100
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 100
 Solve Converged!
  Finished Solving                                                                       [396.00 s] [    0 MB]

Time Step 252, time = 504, dt = 2
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 100
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 1
 Solve Did NOT Converge!
  Finished Solving                                                                       [133.54 s] [    0 MB]
Aborting as solve did not converge

Time Step 252, time = 503, dt = 1
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 100
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 100
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 100
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 100
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 100
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 100
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 100


Any suggestions?
Best
Avtar

Hello @hugary1995
I tried with nl_abs_tol = 1e-6
Still the same issue of huge element deformation is coming.
Length scale for phase field fracture is 4 times the mesh size.
There is anisotropy in the system as well.
I tried with even refined mesh but still no success.
Any other suggestions?
Best
Avtar
The only other possibility that I can think of is the time step size. I would try reducing the time step size by a factor of 10 and see if the issue persists.

Hi @hugary1995
Thank you very much. I am already running a simulation with reduced time step.
I will update you with the results soon.
Best
Avtar

node.title: A force as a BC for a node
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I am looking to apply some force on a point as boundaries condition. I have seen it is possible to use external pressure on my solid, but I prefer a punctual condition. Is it possible?
You will find my mesh and my .i in the following :
Moose_test.zip
Thanks in advance for any help
I stay available
Regards
Alexandre

Hello
I think you can do it.
Create a nodeset with only 1 point in it and specify it as the boundary parameter of the dirichletBCs to apply the load.
Guillaume

I have added a node set (id : 13) and some boundary condition on stress_xx for this node but I get an error message :
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "FEProblem".

No nonlinear variable named stress_xx found. Did you specify an auxiliary variable when you meant to specify a nonlinear variable (or vice-versa)?

I generate this variable with the following :
[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [./all]
    strain = FINITE
    planar_formulation = PLANE_STRAIN
    add_variables = true
    generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_xy stress_yy stress_zz strain_xx strain_xy strain_yy strain_zz'
  [../]
[]

I drop the new version of the mesh/.i
Test_Moose.zip
Thanks

I m not sure you can do that, a BC on stress, like this.
Can you turn on show_var_residual_norm in The [Debug] block when running the case without this boundary condition to see the list of variables

Thanks, I will take a look at the debug block.
And do you know if there is another way to apply an external mechanical force ?
Regards
Alexandre

You can't apply stress_xx as the variable for a dirichlet bc.  The variable for a bc means the variable you are solving for, so it would be disp_x if you want to apply a force in the x direction.  Then you should apply one of the neumann bc's if you want a force.  There might be some examples of using tractions in the tensor mechanics module if you want to use stress.
You also are not using automatic differentiation variables so you need change your bc from ADDirichletBC to just DirichletBC.
Thanks for this answer I will look for this

node.title: Partitioner System
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I recently found the documentation here: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Mesh/Partitioner/index.html to be very interesting and potentially useful for some calculations I am running on HPC.  But I am curious what is the default Partitioner that MOOSE uses?  Is it just GridPartitioner?
On the same note, if I were to leave my executioner block as:
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  start_time = 0.0
  end_time = 2800
[]

for, lets say, a simple TensorMechanics simulation, what are the default solver options?  Are there any PETSc options being used?
Thanks,
Lukasz

MOOSE by default uses metis for partitioning. With parallel runs you can see the partitioner used in the header:
Mesh:
  Parallel Type:           replicated
  Mesh Dimension:          2
  Spatial Dimension:       2
  Nodes:
    Total:                 121
    Local:                 67
    Min/Max/Avg:           54/67/60
  Elems:
    Total:                 100
    Local:                 50
    Min/Max/Avg:           50/50/50
  Num Subdomains:          1
  Num Partitions:          2
  Partitioner:             metis

Similarly, you can see a generic solver summary:
Execution Information:
  Executioner:             Steady
  Solver Mode:             Preconditioned JFNK
  PETSc Preconditioner:    hypre boomeramg

Thats pretty interesting.  My job prints the following under Execution:
Execution Information:
  Executioner:             Transient
  TimeStepper:             FunctionDTGrowth
  Solver Mode:             NEWTON
  MOOSE Preconditioner:    SMP

Even if I add
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'boomerang'

it doesn't change that execution block (meaning I Don't see the PETSc options).  Though, I do see where the partitioner information is now.

I would rely on querying PETSc to see what options are used. I typically use -options_view but I'm sure there's something better:
-mat_mffd_type wp
-options_view
-PC_HYPRE_TYPE boomeramg
-PC_TYPE hypre
-snes_converged_reason ::failed
-snes_mf_operator

is some example output

node.title: Could not import vtk
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I was trying to run the first darcy_thermo_mech included in MOOSE using peacock as illustrated in the Virtual Workshop (summer 2020) using the following command
~/Desktop/moose/projects/moose/python/peacock/peacock -i step1.i
i got the following error:
`Error starting peacock: Could not import vtk
You need to use the miniconda module. Run:
module load miniconda`
I think the issue is the machine i use MacBook Air with M1 chip.

Peacock support on M1 platforms is currently a bit complicated. If you follow the current Getting Started instructions, you'll be running through the Apple Rosetta translation layer for x86. So vtk for Peacock would then be available through the moose-tools (osx-64) package. If using the arm64 version of Mambaforge3, then Peacock is not supported on M1 due to a lack of PyQt5, not vtk.
Based on the above, I have a couple questions - what version of Mambaforge3 are you running? Then, can you check to see if you have moose-tools installed in your conda environment? You can do this by running the command conda list.

```

Peacock is up in the air at the moment on whether or not we can continue to support it. There are other tools available to open results. I suggest using Paraview for now.
The error being displayed by the original poster is a pretty generic one... If you are interested in troubleshooting we can try to dig a bit deeper. The following should produce some output, and create a few image files (by using VTK, which also uses/depends on Qt):
mamba activate moose
export PYTHONPATH=/your/path/to/moose/python
cd /your/path/to/moose/python/chigger/tests/writers
git clean -xfd
./writers.py
Executing writers.py should produce the following output, and create multiple images:
❯ ./writers.py
testError (__main__.TestVTKWriters)
Test that error message is given with an unknown extension. ... ok
testFormats (__main__.TestVTKWriters)
Test that the images are created. ... ok

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 2 tests in 0.294s

OK
The following files should be created:
writers.bmp
writers.jpg
writers.png
writers.ps
writers.tiff

If we can run this simple test up front, it should help prove the basics are functioning.

node.title: SideSetsFromNormalsGenerator support for distributed mesh
node.bodyText:
Hello,
When using SideSetsFromNormalsGenerator with --distributed-mesh flag, it result in an error:
[2] ./include/libmesh/remote_elem.h, line 123, compiled Mar 22 2022 at 20:48:06

[0] ./include/libmesh/remote_elem.h, line 123, compiled Mar 22 2022 at 20:48:06

[1] ./include/libmesh/remote_elem.h, line 123, compiled Mar 22 2022 at 20:48:06


*** ERROR ***
Error: not implemented!



*** ERROR ***
Error: not implemented!



*** ERROR ***
Error: not implemented!

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
MPI_ABORT was invoked on rank 0 in communicator MPI_COMM_WORLD
with errorcode 1.

NOTE: invoking MPI_ABORT causes Open MPI to kill all MPI processes.
You may or may not see output from other processes, depending on
exactly when Open MPI kills them.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
[bell-a094.rcac.purdue.edu:104207] PMIX ERROR: UNREACHABLE in file server/pmix_server.c at line 2193
------------------------------------------------------------
A process or daemon was unable to complete a TCP connection
to another process:
  Local host:    bell-a094
  Remote host:   bell-a095
This is usually caused by a firewall on the remote host. Please
check that any firewall (e.g., iptables) has been disabled and
try again.


You can recreate this problem by running moose/test/tests/meshgenerators/sidesets_from_normals_generator/sidesets_cylinder_normals_fixed.i using --distributed-mesh flag.
Alternatives or quick solutions would be very helpful!
Thanks in advance!
Khaled

If you just need to get going with adding a sideset you can load the mesh in serial, add it then, then use this new file in your distributed script.
You can also add sidesets in cubit.

@KhaledNabilSharafeldin this mesh generator was only implemented for replicated meshes.
In the code you can see that there is an error message for distributed meshes, but it s broken right now. I ll fix it.

I can see that, thanks, this also goes for similar functions as well, I'll look into how mesh generators create them right away/manually adding them.
Any plans to extend the functionality? or is it unlikely?
No plans that I know of

node.title: Crystal plasticity Kalidini model error says you need to provide deformation gradient
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I'm trying to use the "ComputeMultipleCrytalPlasticity" model for Kalidini type and im getting these errors:
Material property 'deformation_gradient', requested by 'stress_ice' is not defined on block 0
Material property 'deformation_gradient', requested by 'stress_ice_face' is not defined on block 0
Material property 'deformation_gradient', requested by 'stress_ice_neighbor' is not defined on block 0

Note that I have added "ComputeFiniteStrain" method to provide this and also I'm using this stress inside my own kernel, therefore I cannot use the tensor mechanics action here. I think the ComputeFiniteStrain method is not providing those info to the plasticity model. here's the input file for my material and kernel (I just put  those parts which might be usefull to read since it's a hige file)
[Materials]
 [./elasticity_tensor_ice]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensorConstantRotationCP
    C_ijkl = '1.684e3 1.214e3 1.214e3 1.684e3 1.214e3 1.684e3 0.754e3 0.754e3 0.754e3'
    fill_method = symmetric9
    block = 0
    base_name = ice
  [../]
  [./stress_ice]
    type = ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress
    crystal_plasticity_models = 'trial_xtalpl'
    tan_mod_type = exact
    maximum_substep_iteration = 200
    use_line_search = true
    min_line_search_step_size = 0.01
    block = 0
    base_name = ice
  [../]
  [./trial_xtalpl]
    type = CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate
    number_slip_systems = 12
    slip_sys_file_name = input_slip_sys.txt
    resistance_tol = 0.01
  [../]
    [./strain_ice]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrain
    displacements = 'u_f_x u_f_y'
    base_name = ice
    block = 0
   #volumetric_locking_correction=true
  [../]
  

Best,
Mahyar

Hello
Have you tried using the TensorMechanicsAction instead of adding the computeFiniteStrain material?
[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master/all]
  strain = FINITE
  add_variables = true
[]

Guillaume

I mentioned in the quation that i cannot use the action since my kernel is coupled with another variables. Is there any way to use the TensorMechanicsAction while my equation looks like this====> (div(sigma*phi) )= 0 in which sigma is stress and phi is phasefield variable coupled to this equation?

are you using any interface kernel, e.g. cohesive zone materials? I asked this because I saw "neighbor" material is being asked.
If you have only one block, you do not need to use "base_name". Leave it as blank or default.

thank you for answering, I'm not using any cohesive zone material but my linear momentum equation is not a simple stress divergence. it is coupled with a phasefield variable which makes it impossible to use tensor mechanics master action. Also im using three different stresses with three different base_names in this equations (since im modeling a multiphase material). For the ice part I wanted to use the crystal plasticity model. So I imagine if ComputeFiniteStress cannot feed my ice_stress the proper deformation gradient then I will not be able to use this model.
If you could attach your input file here, we can take a close look.

Sure here is the input file:
main.txt

I cannot directly run your input file because there are a few customized objects.
I took a close look at the codes. It seems that we need to make a change in line 92 and 93 in ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress by adding a base_name.
_deformation_gradient(getMaterialProperty<RankTwoTensor>(_base_name + "deformation_gradient")), _deformation_gradient_old(getMaterialPropertyOld<RankTwoTensor>(_base_name +"deformation_gradient")),
